loans.use: To buy various products

loans.name: Atalia Dinis

texts.pt:
Atalia nasceu na cidade Maputo, tem 41 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 2 filhos com 14 e 16 anos de idade. Fez 7 classe tendo parado devido à gravidez precoce numa altura em que o governo não permitia que uma aluna grávida continuasse a estudar. Vive com o marido e filhos na casa própria. Não  sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu da cidade de maputo no ano 2000 para boane a procura de melhores condições e oportunidades de negocio. Vem fazendo negocio desde o remoto ano de 1980. Para alem do negocio que faz (venda de produtos de primeiras necessidades) também cria gado bovino e produz horticolas no vale do rio umbeluzi, no distrito de boane.
Na actividade comercial vende arroz, farina e bebidas donde obtêm o rendimento mensal de aprox. 5.500,00MT que aplica no sustento da família e consegue poupar na sua conta bancário no Barclays. O marido não tem emprego formal e vive também de pequenos biscates.

 Este é o primeiro empréstimo da Atalia na Hluvuku-Adsema no valor de 10.000,00MT para compra e venda de produtos de primeira necessidade (arroz, farinha e outros). Já teve empréstimos numa instituição similar que opera no distrito em regime ambulatório, mas depois de concluir decidiu não continuar por varias razoes de varia ordem.

Propõe de na pagar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder a ceder a mais créditos com intuito de fazer crescer o seu negocio, principalmente na próxima quadra festiva.
texts.en:
Atalia was born in the city of Maputo. She is 41 years old, married, and has 2 children, ages 14 and 16. She attended school through the seventh grade when she dropped out due to pregnancy. At that time the government did not permit pregnant girls to continue attending school. She lives with her husband and children in their own home. They do not support anyone else. She left the city of Maputo in 2000 to move to Boane to find better conditions and opportunities for business. She has had her own business since 1980. Besides her running her business (selling commodity goods) she also raises cattle and grows crops in the Umbeluzi river valley, in the Boane district. In her business she sells rice, flour and drinks where she earns approximately 5.500,00 MT monthly. She uses the money to support her family and she manages to save money in her Barclays bank account. Her husband does not have formal employment and does odd jobs. This is Atalia's first loan with Hluvuku-Adsema, in the amount of 10.000,00MT, to be used for the purchase and resale of commodity goods (rice, flour, etc.). She has previously had loans with a similar organization that operated in the district on an ambulatory basis. She decided not to continue with them for various reasons. She plans to pay back the loan without incident in order to have access to future loans with the goal of growing her business, especially during the next holiday season.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and resale of merchandise (rice, flour, etc. )

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame a appris comme métier le transit ; malheureusement, elle n’a pas pu trouver un emploi de transitaire. C’est pour cette raison que grâce à l’aide son mari, elle a ouvert une boutique de débit de boissons dans le quartier de Bè-kpota à Lomé. Cette nouvelle activité lui permet donc depuis 2007 d’apporter elle aussi sa contribution financière dans le foyer pour l’éducation de leur jeune enfant. Sa boutique se situe à côté d’un centre de spectacles et jeux, ce qui fait qu’elle trouve toujours une clientèle prête à se désaltérer. Elle a besoin en ce moment de commander de nouveaux casiers ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 25 casiers de bières et sucreries.

loans.use: Achat de casiers de boissons

loans.name: Fafavi Ayélé

texts.fr: Cette femme n’a pas eu la chance d’apprendre un métier ; c’est cette raison qu’elle a pris la décision l’année dernière de se lancer dans la vente de chaussures au Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle a dressé un petit étalage dans le marché pour pouvoir vendre ses chaussures. Avec ce commerce, elle arrive à subvenir aux besoins de son enfant, puisqu’elle n’est pas mariée. Elle aime bien son activité et compte dans l’avenir associer aussi la vente de sacs de sortie. Elle s’approvisionne auprès de différentes boutiques dans le marché. Elle a un besoin pressant en ce moment d’effectuer de nouveaux achats ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons de chaussures différentes.
texts.en:
Fafavi Ayélé H. did not have the opportunity to learn a trade, which is why she decided last year to start selling shoes at the Great Market of Lomé. She set up a small stand at the market to sell her shoes. This business enables her to provide for her child, since she is not married. She likes this activity very much and expects to be able to sell also handbags in future. She gets her supplies from different stores at the market.

Right now Fafavi urgently needs to buy new shoes. That is why she applies to WAGES for a loan to buy 20 boxes of various shoes.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of shoes

loans.name: God Will Overcome Group

texts.en:
'God Will Overcome' is a group of 5 borrowers led by S. Kanneh, 42 years old, married with 7 children aged 8-29 years old. Their educational levels vary from 1st grade to high school graduate. S. is a 6th grade drop-out due to lack of financial support to continue her education.

S.'s business is preparing sandwiches, bread, and producing juice that can be drunk whilst eating. She works and lives in Dualla market, Bushrod Island, north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia.

S. has been running this business for 9 years and is hoping to improve her business by establishing a fast food center in the future. S. prepares her pastries in a good way to encourage her customers but she sometimes faces difficulty with the price of flour and sugar.

S. needs this loan in order to purchase more food ingredients for her business. She dreams of giving her children the best education.

loans.use: to purchase more food ingredients for her business

loans.name: Ablavi Enyonam

texts.fr: Cette femme est uniquement spécialisée dans la vente d’ignames ; elle exerce ce commerce comme vendeuse ambulante dans le quartier d’Ahligo à Lomé. Elle est mariée et grâce à ce commerce, elle apporte sa contribution financière à son mari pour l’éducation scolaire de leurs 05 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne à Anié, localité située à des dizaines de kilomètres de Lomé. Certains ménages font des commandes chez elle parce qu’elles apprécient beaucoup la qualité de ses ignames. Elle veut à cet effet lancer une nouvelle commande ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle souhaite avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 15 paniers d’ignames.
texts.en:
Ablavi Enyonam A. has specialized in the sole business of selling yams. She walks through the streets of the neighborhood of Ahligo in Lomé to sell her yams. She is married and this business enables her to help her husband financially with the school expenses for their five children. She gets her supplies in Anié, a village located dozens of kilometers from Lomé.

Several households order their yams from Ablavi, because they highly appreciate their quality. Therefore she wants to order a new lot of yams and applies to WAGES for a loan to buy 15 baskets of yams.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy yams

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
When people live on different islands with different cultures, livelihoods, and practices, they tend to be regionalistic and can sometimes be biased against migrants. This was the experience of Manuela P. and her family when unavoidable circumstances forced them to move from the island of Panay to the village of Sitio Napulo, Barangay Cervantes, Escalante City, Negros Occidental.

When they lived in the Province of Iloilo, Manuela's husband earned his living through farming, but when they moved to Escalante, a seaside town where the main activity was fishing, they were like fish out of water. At first life was hard as they adjusted to their new life and new circumstances. Once they adapted to their new environment and assimilated into the local community, the couple started looking for better ways to support their family.

Once settled, she started making new friends in Escalante, and one of them invited her to do something that literally changed her life. When she said yes to her friend to attend an orientation at NWTF-Project Dungganon, Manuela opened a new door in her life. With 3 kids to raise and a family to support, she was receptive to new ideas, and when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997, she decided to invest her first loan into a fishing business, because she observed that it provided a decent living for most of her neighbors. Even with no previous experience, the couple was able to make a go of this new venture, and they were able to payback the first loan.

Striving hard to move out of poverty, they kept focus on their goals, and as the loan amounts available to them increased because of their good business practices and prompt payments, they were eventually able to buy a motorized fishing boat which allowed them to go farther out to sea. They also bought additional fishing nets and crab traps, increasing their income potential.

The business earns a net income of PHP 4,000 per month which helps a lot in supporting their family. She just paid off her previous loan of PHP 7,000, her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, which she used to buy fishing tools. Now she is borrowing PHP 9,000 for her 9th loan cycle to repair their fishing boat and nets so that she and her husband can continue earning a livelihood for their family of five.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To repair their fishing boat and buy fish nets.

loans.name: Fe Y Progreso 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Kirce R. is a young entrepreneur who lives in San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is a member of the group Fe y Progreso (Faith and Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Kirce and her husband Jose have three young children, ages 12, 11, and 3. In order to support her family and send her children through school, Kirce operates a small business selling parts and accessories for motorcycles. As soon as you enter San Pedro, it is easy to see why this is a good business to be in: motorcycles are far and away the most used form of transportation within the city. Drivers called “motoconchos” bring people all over the city, acting as an informal taxi service. Kirce’s products are in high demand, and with this loan she hopes to expand her inventory.

This is Kirce’s fifth loan with Esperanza, and she hopes to continue taking more loans in the future. She hopes that her success in business will lead to a healthier life for her children. She wants them to become professionals in whatever they choose and have a different life than she has had. Thank you for your loan to Kirce and the Fe y Progreso group!

loans.use: Motorcycle parts and accessories

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Having strong family values is always a blessing. Having a common goal for the family is a grace. This is the experience of the L. family. Jessie, who is 54 years old, is married to Renato  and lives in the village of Purok 2, Barangay Carabalan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental.  Their children, the oldest of whom is 27, and the youngest 12, live with them.

She already had a cafeteria beside her house years before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon. It was not much but it helped defray their daily expenses and the education of their children. But it was only after she became a PD member in 2002 that her business expanded. Pouring in more capital to her cafeteria resulted in higher returns, and as she paid off the loans in each cycle, she was able to access even bigger loans because of her good track record of paying on time. Later she decided to turn over the management of the cafeteria to her husband and she set up a vegetable stand in the market to earn additional income. This new arrangement proved to be a wise decision for the couple as their family income grew. She has even started selling household commodities in addition to vegetables to provide her customers with variety. The vegetable stand nets an average monthly income of PHP 4,000 and pays for the education of her children and provides savings. From her earnings, she was able to buy a motorcycle to use in her business.

Over the years, she's kept a her good credit record with NWTF-Project Dungganon. On her previous loan, her 21st loan cycle, she borrowed PHP 25,000 and put it all into her business and fully paid on time without any delays. And for her 22nd cycle she borrowed PHP 26,000 which she intends to use to purchase larger quantities of vegetables and spices to boost her earning capacity. She is planning to invest her income from this cycle to go into the pig-fattening business and also to add to the capital of the cafeteria.  The balance will be used for house repair.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables and spices.

loans.name: Zaki

texts.en: Zaki is a 40-year-old man who lives and works in Hebron, Palestine.  He is the father of 6 children.  In order to support himself and his family, Zaki runs a grocery store.  He is requesting a loan of $2500 so that he can expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store.  He is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: To expand the variety of goods in his store.

loans.name: Mujeres Y Hombres 6| Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group Mujeres y Hombres (Women and Men). Her story is representative of both her group members and Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom recently moved from Haiti to the DR) and Dominican clients. Her group is based in the area surrounding Hato Mayor, a agricultural community which is centered around the sugarcane industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Here she makes her home with her child as a single mother.

Ana came to Esperanza because it offers very low interest rates and she successfully paid back two loans successfully. She is requesting this most recent loan to continue investing in her small variety store. With this loan she will purchase material for curtains and pants. With the profits from this loan she would like to invest in a plot of land on which to build her own home and to improve her life and the life of her daughter. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Fabric for Curtains and Pants

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina T. is a 49-year-old woman living in the village of Taklaron, Brgy. Malingin, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She is married to Eliseo T., who owns and operates a machine shop. They have a 12-year-old child who is currently in school.

Lina and her husband are entrepreneurs. Even before she got married, Lina already had her own general store, while her husband already had his machine shop. When they got married, it looked as if they would have a stable life, with both of them already having their own livelihoods. But sharp economic downturns can befall anyone. At one point, Eliseo wanted to give up his machine shop because he thought that he could no longer afford to buy the necessary spare parts for his machines and he was worried about the competition. But Lina encouraged him to go on and not to lose hope.

Because she was able to spare some of her capital from the general store to help her husband's business, they were able to survive that crisis. That event opened Eliseo's eyes to the fact that, in order to grow, they needed to have additional capital. When he heard about NWTF-Project Dungganon, he encouraged Lina to join, which she did in 2004. From then on she was able to borrow money to use as capital for both the general store and the machine shop, helping both businesses thrive.

On her 4th loan cycle, Lina expanded her general store and also purchased additional materials for her husband's machine shop. Their combined monthly net income from their businesses provides them with 12,000 pesos per month, which they mostly plow back into the businesses after setting some money aside for household expenses and savings for the education of their only child.

For her previous 14th loan cycle, Lina borrowed 19,000 pesos and this amount contributed to the continued success of the family businesses. She was able to pay everything back on time and in full. She plans to borrow 20,000 pesos for her 15th loan cycle, so that she can buy more items to sell in her general store. She plans to use the profits to rent a farm so that she can increase her income even further. She has high hopes for the future of her child.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: To purchase additional items for general store

loans.name: God Bless You Group

texts.en:
Martha J. is the leader of a group of 4  borrowers called 'God bless You'. She is 67 years old, a widow with 4 children aged 24-35 years old. Their educational levels are 12th grade- university graduate. She also cares for 5 siblings.Martha is illiterate due to poverty. She lives and works in the slip way, close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.


Martha's business is buying fish wholesale from fishermen around the coast of Monrovia, Liberia and selling them to residents of downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for more than 20 years, and this business allowed her to educate her children.

Martha started this business with a little fund given her by her late husband, and with hardwork and serious attention, she has reached this far. Martha always sell good fish to her customers in order to retain them. She needs this loan to purchase more goods to expand her business.

Martha dreams of growing  her fish business to a higher standard so that she and her childrem can become successful in life.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to expand her business

loans.name: Kareem

texts.en:
Kareem is a 23 year old single man who lives in Nablus city,Palestine with his parents.He is a  grateful son who works very hard at construction in order to support his family. He is the one who handles all the family's expenses with a meager wage from construction.
Kareem is requesting a $1000 loan to help him in purchasing some construction tools to facilitate his job .He thanks Kiva and all its lenders for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing construction tools

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Even though she has only one daughter, Melanie H. still works hard to earn a living because she wants to provide her daughter with financial security. She is a 43-year-old woman, living in the village of Brgy. Canggapas Anahaw, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. Melanie is married to Jose H., a truck driver who delivers sugarcane from the farm to the sugar mill. Driving a truck, in an industry that is known for its seasonality, cannot provide even a small family with a stable source of income. Even less, when the actual amount he receives for his labor is examined.

With no guaranteed income from her husband for part of the year to rely on for their family's needs, Melanie decided to earn her own living to supplement whatever income her husband earns and to provide their family with a more stable financial resource. When she was ready to start her business, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access a collateral-free loan it offers, and used it to set up a general store. 

As her earnings grew, and her customer base expanded, she saw another opportunity for expansion - offering electronic reloading to prepaid mobile phone subscribers, many of whom were already patronizing her general store. With the fast turnover of her business she was able to increase her income. She now earns a monthly average of 7,000 pesos from her general store. Her industriousness has paid off:  she is happy to report that her daughter has graduated from college.

In her previous 16th loan cycle, she was able to borrow 19,000 pesos which was used as additional capital for her business. She paid back all of the weekly installments on time, keeping her good credit rating with NWT-Project Dungganon. She is planning to borrow 19,000 pesos for her 17th loan cycle to support her general store and electronic reloading business.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store and electronic reloading business

loans.name: Mujeres Con Propositos 1 And 2 Group

texts.en:
Ramona is the group coordinator of the Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Mujeres con Propositos (Women with Purpose).  Her story is representative of both her group and of Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom have recently immigrated to the DR) and Dominican clients.  The group is based in Puerto Plata, a community with unreliable electricity and water services.  The community does not have access to some basic services like trash collection. 

Ramona is a single mother with five children. This will be Ramona's third loan with Esperanza.  She has successfully repaid two loans of increasing amounts and wants to use this loan to buy ingredients for her food sales.  She plans to buy flour, oil and salt to make empanadas and other pastries. She hopes to continue to grow her business with this loan.

Ramona has been able to provide for her children and improve the supplies she can provide for them since receiving loans from Esperanza. She has also used her profit to pay for her university studies.

loans.use: Flour, Oil, Salt and other materials to make empanadas and pastries

loans.name: Primero De Julio Group

texts.es: Marina Máxima A. presidenta del grupo “1ro de Julio”, que pertenece al Centro Focal “Collpani”, lleva adelante su reunión y entre todas  elaboran el reglamente interno. Todas sus integrantes tienen diversas actividades económicas como la venta de verduras, atención de tienda de barrio, venta de alimentos secos, dulces, carne, pollos y venta de alimento balanceado. Un ejemplo claro es Carmen M. de 42 años, madre de 5 hijos, se dedica a vender alimento para animales, en la feria 16 de Julio y trabaja con Pro Mujer hace 1 ½  aproximadamente, durante este tiempo ha podido sacar adelante su negocio, ya que con el primer préstamo se ha comprado se ha comprado mercadería y carrito para trasladar su mercadería. Ahora necesita el préstamo para comprar mayor mercadería, como afrecho, afrechillo, frangollo y harina amarilla. Todas ellas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería y materia prima.
texts.en:
Marina Máxima A. is president of the Primero de Julio Group, which belongs to the Collpani community center. She leads the meetings, and everyone makes their internal rules. All of the members have diverse economic activities like selling vegetables, tending a neighborhood store, selling dried food, sweets, meat, chickens, and selling balanced food. One clear example is Carmen M.. She is 42 and has five children. She sells animal food in the 16 de Julio fair. She has worked with Pro Mujer for approximately one and a half years. During this time she has been able to get ahead in her business. With her first loan she bought merchandise and a cart to transport her merchandise. She now needs a loan to buy more merchandise like bran, corn mash, and yellow flour. All of them need the loan to buy merchandise and raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise and raw material

loans.name: Esperanza Del Barrio Azul Group

texts.en:
Marie L. M. (second from right in picture) is a borrower from the town of San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for the group Esperanza del Barrio Azul (Hope of the Blue Neighborhood), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in her group.

Marie is 35 years old and lives with her husband Isidro, her 19-year-old daughter, and also cares for a 14-year-old girl. Marie makes and sells sweets to her neighbors and friends, specializing with the local supply of coconut and peanuts. Since sweets are a luxury, Marie would like to use this loan to purchase rice and maybe some clothing that she can sell for a profit. These items will help her keep a steady income when the sales of her sweets aren’t as high.

This is Marie’s 3rd loan with Esperanza, and she has a perfect repayment record. She hopes that her two girls will have better lives due to her increase in profits. Marie is very thankful for her loan and her relationship with Esperanza, saying “when I have difficulties with my business, I know I can come [to Esperanza] for support”. Thank you for your loan to Marie and to the Esperanza del Barrio Azul group!

loans.use: Supplies for candy, rice, and clothing

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna C.'s an entrepreneur who values her time - she says that time is gold so she does not waste any of it, if she can do something to earn money to achieve her dream faster. She is a 50-year-old widow who lives in the town of Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She has one big long-term dream and several smaller ones. Her biggest dream is to be able to renovate her house, improve her living standards and help her granddaughter afford higher education.

Her smaller, and maybe more immediate dream, is to be able to buy a tricycle (a motorcycle with a side car for passengers or goods) so that she can easily travel from town to town in pursuit of her business. Edna, or "Nanay Edna" (Mother Edna) as most people call her, has an ambulatory business selling fruits in different towns during their market day. She is so focused on her goals that she does not mind the rain or the heat of the sun if her efforts bring her one step nearer to the achievement of her dreams.

Nanay Edna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 to increase the volume of fruits she offers for sale – in effect also increasing her income potential. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 pesos for her tireless efforts. She is very prompt in her payments, and follows all the rules, depositing her payment in the bank a day before the scheduled weekly NWTF-PD Center meeting. She pays directly to the bank to avoid any untoward incidents.

For her previous loan, she got 19,500 pesos which was quite a lot of capital for her, but she was able to fully pay her loan on time and within the term set. This time around, for her ninth loan cycle, she has requested the same amount, 19,500 pesos, to be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital for her business. Income from the business will be used for house improvements.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Mujeres Y Hombres 7 Group

texts.en:
Juana is the group coordinator of the group Mujeres y Hombres 7 (Men and Women). Her story is representative of both the members of her group and Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) and Dominican clients. Her group is based in the area around Hato Mayor, an agricultural town in the center of the DR based around the sugarcane harvest where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Here she makes her home with her child as a single mother.

Juana originally came to Esperanza because she wanted the opportunity to be a businesswoman and after having successfully repaid her first loan she is ready for her second. She plans to use this loan to invest in more colthing and shoes which she plans to buy in bulk at a better price. She plans to use the additional profits from her improve her life by purchasing a house, clothing and shoes for her child, books for school and school supplies for her child. Her long term dream is to own her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Clothes and shoes

loans.name: Aura Luz

texts.es: Aura Luz P. R. tiene 49 años. Su actividad económica es el destace de cerdo y elaboración de nacatamales. Hace más de 26 años que se dedica a esta actividad. Aura tiene 2 hijos que dependen de ella y asisten a un colegio público ya que con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado que sus hijo tengan están oportunidad. Ella inicio con este negocio desde muy temprana edad, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación ya que es aquí donde realiza la elaboración del delicioso platillo del nacatamal, por lo que después del destace procede a la elaboración de este platillo tan típico, Aura es una mujer muy responsable además disfruta mucho de trabajo. Actualmente solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de materia prima. El deseo de Aura es construir su propia casa.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: God's Center Group

texts.en:
'God's Center' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Janjay B., 34 years old,  married with 3 children aged 4-7 years old. Janjay is illiterate because most rural Liberian prefer farming rather than sending their children to school. She sells foodstuffs and used clothing at the waterside market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Janjay started this business with Ld$ 5000 that was given to her by her husband, and she has been running this business for 10 years. She buys good quality goods and prepares them very well to attract customers.

Janjay needs this loan in order to purchase more goods. She has hopes of expanding her business to a bigger shop and dreams of giving her children quality education so they can become successful.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for resale

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr: Cette femme est accoucheuse de profession ; elle s’est divorcée de son mari et a à sa charge ses 03 enfants. En 2000, elle a ouvert une petite clinique dénommée « Secours Médical… » dans le quartier d’Akodessewa à Lomé. Beaucoup de clientes lui font confiance ; elle donne des conseils et premiers soins pour femmes enceintes. Aussi, elle profite de cette occasion pour vendre des produits génériques à ses clientes. Son stock est presque fini en ce moment ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 10 litres d’alcool, de sparadras, des boîtes de paracétamol et autres produits.
texts.en:
Akoua D. is a professional midwife. She is divorced and provides for her three children. In 2000, she opened a small clinic named "Secours Médical…" ("Medical Aid …") in the neighborhood of Akodessewa in Lomé. Many clients trust her; she gives advice and first aid to pregnant women. Consequently she takes the opportunity to sell generic drugs to her customers. Her inventory is almost depleted at this moment. That is why she applies to WAGES for a loan to order 10 liters of alcohol, plasters, packs of paracetamol and other items.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic drugs

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es: Víctor Manuel Z. P. tiene 42 años, su actividad económica es la venta y elaboración de ladrillos. Hace más de 30 años que se dedica a este negocio. Inicialmente este negocio era de su Padre quien le enseño todo lo necesario para aprendiera muy bien este oficio que sería su medio de vida. Víctor es un hombre trabajador y luchador, y le ha enseñado a sus hijos a ganarse el dinero muy humildemente. Con los financiamientos ha podido obtener lo necesario para su negocio. Actualmente solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de leña, arena, barro entre otras cosas para la fabricación. El sueño de Víctor es tener el suficiente capital para poder trabajar con mayor capacidad de producción.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Mujeres Activas, Group 1, 2, 3

texts.en:
Teresita runs a small market stall selling clothes, food and other items.  She has operated her store for over eight years and her loans have allowed her to increase her business by 80%.  She plans to use this loan to buy a box of used clothes and food items to sell.  She has successfully repaid two loans and this will be her third loan with Esperanza.  Teresita is single and has three grown children.  She wants to continue to increase her business and add more products to her store. 
 
Teresita is the group coordinator of the Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Mujeres Activas (Active Women).  Her story is representative of both her group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian clients (many of whom have recently immigrated to the DR).  The group is based in Puerto Plata in a community that has unreliable access to running water and electricity and lacks trash service.

loans.use: A box of used clothing and food items to sell

loans.name: Xiomara

texts.en: Xiomara is a new borrower with Esperanza International. She lives in San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic, with her husband, Pablo, and children ages 12, 10, and 6. Xiomara runs a small pharmacy called "D’Xioma Pruducto Natural" (Xiomara’s Natural Products) where she sells medicine to her neighbors. With the flu season upon us, Xiomara will be quite busy in the next couple of months. With this loan, she will focus her sales on flu remedies and antibiotics. Xiomara believes that this loan will bring in enough additional profits to greatly benefit her family. She wants to send her children to university and, with an expanding business, she will be able to do just that. Thank you for your loan to Xiomara!

loans.use: To buy antibiotics and flu medicines

loans.name: Rosa Natividad

texts.es:
El banco comunal Unión Progresista se encuentra ubicado a unos 45 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, vía a el Valle en la comunidad de Ñariviña, aquí podemos disfrutar de unos hermosos paisajes siendo una comunidad que nos brinda la libertad de estar en el campo, respirar aire puro y admirar la belleza natural de nuestro ciudad.

La señora Rosa Natividad M. vive en el barrio de Pillcha Calchi Chico en la  comunidad de Ñariviña, tiene 26 años, vive en unión libre fruto de esa unión concibió tres  hijos de:  8, 5, 1,5 año de edad, su primera hija estudia en la escuela de la comunidad de Inga Pirca, su hijo de 5 años es minusválido tiene parálisis cerebral epática, no tienen casa propia al momento  viven en una casa pequeña de tablas  prestada por un familiar, mientras que su  esposo trabaja en su aserradero siendo su gran apoyo para sobrellevar la enfermedad de su pequeño hijo.

Rosa  trabaja junto a su esposo en el aserradero, llevan varios años en este negocio, ella debe combinar su trabajo con las actividades del hogar y sobre todo con el cuidado de su hijo que necesita mayor atención y  cuidados especiales.

Dentro de su banco comunal Rosa es una socia muy alegre y solidaria, trabaja junto a la fundación desde hace tres años y nos manifiesta que los créditos recibidos le ha permitido mantener el aserradero bien abastecido,  con el préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue  va a invertir en la compra  de madera para  su negocio, dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes e  incrementar  el mismo para  darles a sus hijos un mejor futuro.

El sueño de Rosa es  llegar a tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
The Unión Progresista Communal Bank is located 45 minutes from the city of Cuenca on the way to El Valle in the Ñariviña community. Here we can enjoy the beautiful scenery because it is a community that offers the freedom of being in the country, breathing fresh air, and admiring the natural beauty of our city. Rosa Natividad M. lives in the Pillcha Carchi Chico neighborhood in the Ñariviña community. She is 26 and in a common law marriage. They have three children, ages 8, 5, and 1. Her oldest daughter goes to the Inga Pirca community school. Her five year old son is disabled. He has Cerebral Palsy. They do not have their own house. At the moment they live in a small house made of boards, which a relative lent them. Her husband works in his sawmill. He is a great support in dealing with her small son’s illness. Rosa works with her husband in the sawmill. They have had the business for several years. She has to combine her work with her household chores, especially taking care of her son who needs more attention and special care. Within her communal bank Rosa is a very happy and supportive member. She has worked with the foundation for three years. The loans she has received have allowed her to keep the sawmill well stocked. With the loan from Fundación ESPOIR she will buy wood for her business, give her customers better service, and increase the number of customers she has in order to give her children a better future. Rosa’s dream is to have her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood to stock her sawmill

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nou Solid Group

texts.en:
Rodelet S. is a single father with two small children. This hardworking family man owns a boutique where he sells cold drinks, snacks, sugar, oil and a variety of other small household items. He attributes the recent development in his area to Esperanza’s work and is happy to participate in the process. He would like to see his business advance and create a more stable economic situation for his children.

Rodelet S. is one of three representatives of the group “Nou Solid”, or "We are Solid", Bank of Hope. The group is made up of 15 men and women entrepreneurs. The group is very excited about receiving their first loan from Esperanza. After hearing so many good things about the work that other associates have been doing with their loans, the day has finally come for the Nou Solid group to have their own experience. On behalf of Nou Solid, Rodelet, and Esperanza we thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks, snacks, sugar and oil

loans.name: Ruth Y Esther 2 Group

texts.en:
Mariluz is the coordinator of her Banco D. Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Paz y Fe (peace and faith.) Her story is representative of both the members of her group and Eseperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients. Her group is based in the Samana peninsula in the east of the Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unavailable. Here she makes her home alone as a single mother of two children.

Mariluz has come to Esperanza with the goal of starting her own business and she is excited to take out her first loan. She has identified a market for underwear in her community and she will be investing in a dozen pairs of underwear, a dozen brassieres and a dozen undershirts. She plans to use the profits from this business to afford the daily costs of having a family from food to clothing as well as to purchase school supplies for her children. In the long term her goal is to own her own house where she can raise her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Brassieres, undershirts and underwear

loans.name: Luz Zenaida

texts.es:
El banco comunal Unión Progresista se encuentra ubicado a unos 45 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, vía al Valle en la comunidad de Ñariviña, aquí podemos disfrutar de unos hermosos paisajes siendo una comunidad que nos brinda la libertad de estar en el campo, respirar aire puro y admirar la belleza natural de nuestra ciudad. 

La señora Luz L. vive en la comunidad de Pichicay en  la parroquia  Santa Ana, es una joven de  24 años,  es madre soltera de un hijo de 1 año 11 meses de edad, su niño no es reconocido por su padre, ella trabaja como empleada doméstica hace ya varios años para mantener  a su hijo, no tiene casa propia por lo que  vive con su madre.

Luz tiene una buena amistad con todas las socias de su banco comunal, lleva trabajando junto a la fundación tres años, con los créditos obtenidos ha cancelado algunas deudas, mientras que con el préstamo que ESPOIR le entregue va a invertir en la compra de  muebles para su hogar.

El  sueño de Luz es  llegar a tener su  propio  criadero de pollos actividad de corto ciclo y que además deja buenas ganancias para compartir mas tiempo con su niño.
texts.en:
The Unión Progresista Communal Bank is located 45 minutes outside of the city of Cuenca on the way to El Valle in the Ñariviña community. Here we can enjoy beautiful scenery because it is a community that offers the freedom of being in the country, breathing fresh air, and admiration for the natural beauty of this city. Luz L. lives in the Pichicay community in the Santa Ana parish. She is a 24 year old single mother with a child who is one year and eleven months old. Her child is not acknowledged by his father. She works as a domestic employee. She has done this for several years to support her son. She does not have her own house; she lives with her mother. Luz has a nice friendship with all of the other members of her communal bank. She has been working with the foundation for three years. With the loans she has received, she has paid some debts. With the loan from ESPOIR she will buy furniture for her home. Luz’s dream is to have her own chicken coop. This is an activity with a short cycle, and it also produces good income. Then she could spend more time with her son.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy furniture for her home

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.en:
Ignacia T. is the group coordinator of the group Mujeres Emprendedoras 3 (Entrepreneurial Women). Her story is representative of both the members of her group and Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) and Dominican clients. She lives in Puerto Plata, on the north coast of the Dominican Republic, is unmarried and does not have children. She lives in a town without clean running water and without a reliable supply of electricity.

To make a living, Ignacia has been selling clothes for about a year now. She would like a loan to purchase more clothes to appeal to more customers. She dreams of one day having a permanent storefront.

This is Ignacia's second loan with Esperanza. She says that Esperanza has maD. a large impact in her life by giving her the means to expand her business and the ability to better proviD. for herself.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing inventory/merchandise.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo D. L. is 38 years old and lives in San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic with his wife and three children，who range in age from ten months to ten years. Bernardo has a physical disability, but he does not let it stop him from running a successful business. He operates a fruit stand; selling apples, bananas, passion fruit, and pineapple at the steps of his home.

This is Bernardo’s third loan with Esperanza, which he hopes will allow him to offer a greater variety of fresh fruits. Bernardo and his wife will use their profits to repair their home. He hopes that, one day, he will be able to have a more professional fruit stand.

Thank you for lending to Bernardo!

loans.use: To be able to offer a greater variety of fresh fruits.

loans.name: Vilma Susana

texts.es:
El banco comunal Unión Progresista se encuentra ubicado a unos 45 minutos  a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, vía al Valle en la comunidad de Ñariviña, aquí podemos disfrutar de unos hermosos paisajes siendo una comunidad que nos brinda la libertad de estar en el campo, respirar aire puro y admirar la belleza natural de nuestra tierra.

La señora Vilma B. vive en la comunidad de Ñariviña, en la parroquia Santa Ana, tiene 46 años de edad, vivía  en unión libre pero se separó hace seis años porque su conviviente se convirtió en un borracho e irresponsable;  procreó  ocho  hijos de:  26, 25, 24, 22, 18, 16, 15, 12 años de edad, casi todos sus hijos trabajan  y estudian en un colegio a distancia, ellos le ayudan un poco  con los gastos de la casa excepto su última hija que estudia en el colegio Ecuador.  Vive con toda su familia en  casa de uno de sus hijos que se encuentra en el exterior.

Vilma trabaja criando pollos, también se dedica a otras actividades como lavar ropa y arreglar casas ajenas solo cuando alguien le pide, este es un ingreso adicional  para ayudarse un poco porque la situación económica para vivir está muy dura y mucho más para una mujer sola, acota.  

Tiene una buena amistad con todas sus compañeras del banco comunal, este en su tercer ciclo trabajando con la Fundación y nos comenta que los créditos la han ayudado mucho para mantener su negocio;  con el préstamo que la institución le entregue  va a invertir en la compra de  más pollos, comida y vitaminas para incrementar su criadero. 

El sueño de Vilma es  reunir dinero para algún día construir su casa propia.
texts.en:
The Unión Progresista Communal Bank is located 45 minutes outside of the city of Cuenca on the way to El Valle in the Ñariviña community. Here we can enjoy beautiful scenery because it is a community that offers the freedom of being in the country, breathing fresh air, and admiration for the natural beauty of this city. Vilma B. lives in the Ñariviña community in the Santa Ana parish. Ana is 46, and she was in a common law marriage. She separated six years ago because her life partner became an irresponsible drunk. She has eight children; 26, 25, 24, 22, 18, 16, 15, and 12. Almost all of her children work and go to a school some distance away. They help a little with the household expenses. Her last daughter goes to the Ecuador school. She lives with all of her family in the house of one of her sons who is in the exterior. She works raising chickens. She also does other activities like washing clothes and fixing up other houses when someone asks for this service. This is an additional income that helps a little. The economic living situation is very hard, and even harder for a woman alone. She has a nice friendship with all of her colleagues in the communal bank. This is her third cycle working with the Foundation. The loans have helped a lot in maintaining her business. With the loan from the institution she will buy more chickens, food, and vitamins to increase her chicken business. Vilma’s dream is to get together enough money to one day build her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chickens, vitamins, and food to raise chickens and increase her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Las Morlaquitas(Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Morlaquitas está  ubicado en la ciudad de Cuenca al Sur del Ecuador,  éste banco está conformado por un grupo de mujeres luchadoras que tienen una visión muy amplia de la vida, quieren dejar atrás todo aquello que pueda truncar su futuro y el de su familia pues  tienen mucha confianza que cada día les va a ir mejor  y podrán proporcionar a su familia un poco de la vida que siempre desearon tener, demostrando  que con mucho esfuerzo y empeño todo se puede lograr, todas las socias del banco viven en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca.

La señora  Luisa Narcisa  T. A.  es socia  activa del Banco Comunal Morlaquitas, vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca en el  Sector de la Feria Libre, tiene 45 años de edad, es divorciada  desde 13 años porque su vida matrimonial no fue la que esperaba,  pues su ex marido con frecuencia la agredía física y psicológicamente, ya que en su hogar nunca existió comprensión, tiene 2 hijos de 23, 13 años de edad, su hijo mayor  trabaja en ETAPA (Empresa Municipal de Telecomunicaciones, Agua Potable, Alcantarillado y Sanitario de Cuenca) y estudia en el Sindicato de Choferes Profesionales del Azuay, su hijo menor estudia en un colegio de la localidad, no tienen casa propia por lo que  la casa en la que habitan es arrendada.

Luisa tiene su  profesión de estilista hace varios años, tiene 4 años en su local en la ciudad de Cuenca y 20 en la parroquia de Quingueo,  además se dedica a la venta de productos para la belleza de la mujer  YANBAL, en éste último  lleva seis años y nos comenta que tiene su propia clientela además le va muy bien en las dos actividades.

Luisa es una de las socias más alegres de su  banco comunal, trabaja junto a la fundación cinco ciclos y da testimonio que los créditos obtenidos  le han beneficiado de muchos apuros económicos que le han surgido y  ha logrado hacer crecer su negocio incrementando la línea de cosméticos Yanbal.

 Con el préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue lo va a invertir en la compra de más productos YANBAL  para incrementar su negocio con cosméticos para damas, caballeros y niños.
 
El gran sueño de Luisa es que su hijo llegue a culminar los estudios superiores.

La señora Soraya de Lourdes Arízaga  A. es otra socia del Banco Comunal Morlaquitas, vive en San Pedro vía a Racar en la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 33 años de edad, es felizmente casada  tiene una niña de 2 años 7 meses, su esposo trabaja en la embotelladora Cristal lo que le permite aportar económicamente a su hogar buscando la estabilidad económica que necesitan, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.


Soraya es comerciante de ropa colombiana por catalogo lleva tres años en este negocio, y hace dos meses abrió una pequeña tienda en su casa,  comenta que le va muy  bien  pues ya cuenta con su clientela fija, esta actividad la realiza puerta a puerta en su barrio dándoles comodidad a sus clientes porque les entrega la mercadería y cobra  en el domicilio con el propósito de darles un buen servicio  y obtener más clientela, y hace dos meses abrió una pequeña tienda en su casa.

Soraya es una mujer emprendedora y carismática,  mantiene una buena relación con sus compañeras del banco comunal, lleva trabajando tres ciclos en su banco y asegura que los créditos recibidos le han ayudado mucho para mantener su negocio de ropa y para montar su tienda. Con el préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue  va a invertir en productos para su tienda, surtirla con vA. líneas y dar un buen servicio a sus clientes.

El mayor  sueño de nuestra socia  es tener su propio almacén de ropa.
texts.en:
The Morlaquitas Communal Bank is located in the city of Cuenca in the southern part of Ecuador. This bank is comprised of women who are fighters and have a very large vision for their lives. They want to leave behind all that could curtail their future and that of their families. They are confident that each day will go better, and they will be able to give their families a little bit of life that they have always wanted to have. They demonstrate that with much effort and strength you can achieve everything. All of the members of the bank live in the area of the city of Cuenca. Luisa Narcisa T. A. is an active member of the Morlaquitas Communal Bank. She lives in the area of the city of Cuenca in the Sector de la Feria Libre. She is 45, and she has been divorced for 13 years. Her marital life was not what she hoped for. Her ex-husband attacked her physically and psychologically. Understanding never existed in her home. She has two children, 23 and 13. Her oldest son works in ETAPA (Municipal Business of Telecommunications, Potable Water, Sewage and Sanitation of Cuenca) and studies in the Professional Drivers Syndicate of Azuay. Her youngest son goes to the local school. They do not have they own house, so they live in a rented house. Luisa has been a stylist for several years. She has been in her place in the city of Cuenca for four years. She has been in the Quingeo parish for 20 years. She also has been selling women’s Yanbal beauty products for six years. She has her own customers, and it is going well for her in both activities. Luisa is one of the happiest members of her communal bank. She has worked with the foundation for five cycles. She says that the loans she got have helped her in the times of economic hardships she has encountered. They suggested, and she achieved making her business grow by increasing the Yanbal line of cosmetics. With the loan from the ESPOIR Foundation she will buy more Yanbal products to increase the number of women’s, men’s, and children’s cosmetics in her business. Luisa’s big dream is that her son completes his post high school education. Soraya de Lourde Arízaga A. is another member of the Morlaquitas Communal Bank. She lives in San Pedro on the way to Racar in the city of Cuenca. She is 33, happily married, and has a daughter who is two years and seven months. Her husband works in the Cristal bottling plant, which allows him to provide for his household, while looking for the economic stability that they need. They do not have their own house, so they live in a rented house. Soraya sells Columbian clothing by catalog. She has been in this business for three years. Two months ago she opened a small store in her house. She says that it is going very well for her. She has a fixed customer base. She does this activity door to door in her neighborhood, providing her customers with the convenience of delivering and collecting payment in their home. She does this to give good service and get more customers. Two months ago she opened a small store in her house. Soraya is an enterprising and charismatic woman. She has a good relationship with her colleagues in the communal bank. She has been working with the bank for three cycles, and she affirms that the loans she has received have helped her maintain her clothing business and start her store. With the loan from the ESPOIR Foundation she will buy products for her store, stock it with various lines, and give good service to her customers. Her biggest dream is to have her own clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise like perfume, cosmetics, clothing for the entire family to increase their businesses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Peniel, Group 7

texts.en:
Patria is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Samana.  She is the coordinator of the Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Peniel.  Her story is representative of the other women in her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients.  Samana is a community with unreliable electricity and running water. 

This is Patria's first loan with Esperanza.  She came to Esperanza for a loan because she wants to open a cafe and work for herself. She plans to use the loan to buy food to sell in her cafe including: cookies, cheese, and juice.  She will also buy a toaster. 

Patria wants to start a business so that she can improve the living conditions for her family.  She would like to buy a house, a washing machine and shoes for her children. She hopes to continue to invest in her business in the future.

loans.use: Items to sell in a cafe including: cookies, cheese, and juice

loans.name: Luz Y Progreso Group

texts.en:
Mirlanda is the coordinator of her bank of hope: Luz y Progreso (Light and Progress). Her story is representative of both the members of her group and Eseperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients. Her group is based in the Samana peninsula in the east of the Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unavailable. She and her children call "home" a simple structure of wooden walls with a tin roof.

Mirlanda first came to Esperanza with the goal of starting a business and she is now on her third loan after having succesfully repaid the first two. She will use this third loan to reinvesting in her business by purchasing a display case as well as additional accessories to sell: necklaces, gold chains and earrings.

She plans to use the increased profits to purchasing various things for her family, including: animals to be raised for food and tools for her children's educatoin - books, backpacks and a computer. Her long-term goal is to finish repairing and improving her home and to invest in a new location for her business that will attract more customers.

She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase a display case and additional accessories to sell.

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Native de Koutiala, dans la troisième  région administrative de la république,  Madame Rokia Cissé est  âgée  de 34 ans mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari et  ses enfants dans le quartier Koko de la préfecture  de Koutiala.  
N’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, Rokia Cissé  s’intéressa très vite aux activités génératrices de revenus  qu’elle appris auprès de sa maman. Après avoir mener plusieurs activités, elle opta finalement pour la vente d’habits  depuis maintenant  10 ans.  Cette activité  rentable  lui  procure assez de  revenus car elle reçoit des commandes à travers des associations féminines pour leurs uniformes.  
En vu d’élargir son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter,  40 pièces  de tissus wax. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente, d’une façon ambulante dans la ville de Koutiala, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant ou à crédit .  
Avec cette augmentation de son chiffre d’affaire, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 70.000 FCFA  qu’elle utilisera  pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, contribuer aux  dépenses  de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born in Koutiala, in the third administrative region of the Republic, Mrs. Rokia Cissé, 34, is married and the mother of 5 children. She lives in a monogamous family with her husband and her children in the Koko district of the prefecture of Koutiala.

Not having had the good fortune to attend school, Rokia Cissé busied herself with earning a living, learning from her mother. After having tried out several businesses, she finally decided to sell cloth, which she has been doing for 10 years now. This lucrative business brings her in a good deal of profit, since she gets orders from various women's associations for their uniforms.

With an eye to expanding her business and satisfying her clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she is on her first individual loan.

With this loan she intends to buy 40 lengths of African "waxcloth." She does her buying in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers and makes her sales on foot in and around the town of Koutiala, to a clientele composed of women and men, retail and for cash or credit.

With this increase in her turnover, she expects a monthly profit of 70,000 F CFA which she will use to pay the interest on the loan, contribute to family expenses, and then invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing African waxcloth

loans.name: God Mercy Group

texts.en:
'God Mercy' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Eslie C., 53 years old and a widow with 7 children aged 21-35; their educational levels: 11th grade-college graduate. Eslie also cares for 5 siblings.

Eslie's business is food preparation.She prepares home food right in front of her house in Pipe Lines, Paynes Ville in the capital, Monrovia, Liberia. 
She started with doing a part-time job, saved, and later decided to get into business 29 years ago.

Eslie prepares her food like good home food that her customers will always want to buy from her. She needs this loan in order to expand her food preparation business.

Eslie dreams of making her children successful so that their father's name will remain.

loans.use: to expand her food preparation business

loans.name: Prosperidad Y Amistad Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “Prosperidad y Amistad”  se encuentra ubicada en la parte alta D. Huaycan distrito D. Ate departamento D. Lima, representada por la señora Mariza Fernández, quien actualmente asume el cargo D. presidenta, ella es  natural D.  Chanchamayo – La Merced, tiene 47 años y 4 hijos.
Empezaron a trabajar con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad desD. hace unos días, la alcancía comunal esta  conformada por 12 socios quienes desempeñan diferentes tipos D. actividades como: venta D. verduras, venta D. comida, venta D. ropa, venta D. abarrotes, venta D. salchipollo, tejidos y trabajos manuales, confección y venta D. polos y en cuanto los socios se dedican a actividades como operario D. construcción, servicio D. soldador y también prestan servicio D. chofer D. transporte públicos. Algunas socios  desarrollan sus actividades en su domicilio y el resto son ambulantes, ya que el  entorno competitivo es muy fuerte pero los socios cuentan con clientes fidealizados  gracias a al buen trabajo o por contar con productos D. calidad. El destino del reciente préstamo será para la adquisición D. mercadería para surtir sus productos e insumos y materiales para sus negocios y herramientas que ayuden a realizar un mejor trabajo. Sus expectativas son tener mayores ingresos para brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida así como tener una economía más estable para ir mejorando la educación D. nuestros hijos. Los socios estamos agradecidos y muy entusiasmados D. poder trabajar con la institución y nos comprometemos a seguir trabajando y no defraudarlos.
texts.en:
The community bank "Prosperity and Friendship" is located in the high part of the Huaycan district of the Ate department of Lima. It is represented by Mrs. Mariza F. who currently has the position of president. She is a native of Chanchamayo - La Merced, is 47 years old and has 4 children. They started working with EDAPROSPO- Prosperity several days ago. The community bank is composed of 12 members who work at various types of activities such as : sale of vegetables, sale of prepared food, sale of clothing, sale of groceries, sale of salchipollo (a chicken and french fries dish), knits and other handiwork, making and sale of shirts, some members also work as operators in construction, proviD. soldering services and transportation services as in public auto drivers. Some members work in their homes and others are street vendors. The environment is very competitive, however, the members have faithful customers due to their good work and quality products. The purpose for this loan will be to acquire merchandise to improve the supply of their products and ingredients and raw materials for their businesses, also tools for them to improve their work. They expect to have more income to be able to give their families a better way of life and also to improve the local economy and continue improving the education of the children. The members are very grateful and excited to be able to work with the institution and they promise to continue to work and not disappoint it.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To acquire merchandise to improve the supply of their products and ingredients and raw materials for their businesses.

loans.name: Amados Por Dios Group

texts.es:
Los socios D. la alcancía  comunal “Amados por Dios”; esta conformada por 10 socios, ellos  tienen como afinidad, D. que todos viven en el mismo barrio las Brisas D. California, esta ubicado en la parte alta D. la entrada D. los Ángeles del distrito D. Chosica - Lurigancho, departamento D. Lima
Trabajan con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad desD. hace unos días, actualmente asume el cargo D. presidenta la señorita Margarita L., natural D. Tacna, soltera se dedica a la venta D. comida desD. hace 1 año. Los socios desempeñan diversas actividades, una D. ellas a la venta D. productos D. belleza, el otro es ebanista independiente, una venD. comidas a los obreros, la otra se dedica a la preparación y venta D. caldo D. gallina, 2 se dedican a la extracción, procesamiento y venta D. oro, una es profesora D. tejidos, otra socia se dedica a  trabajos comunales, tejidos artesanales y 2 prestan servicio D. chofer D. taxi.
Con el reciente préstamo otorgado a Margarita lo invertirá en la compra D. ollas grandes y utensilios D. cocina, todos los socios tenemos el deseo D. incrementar nuestras ganancias e invertir para mejorar sus ingresos, para mejorar la calidad D. vida y educación D. nuestros hijos.
Nuestros socios agradecen el apoyo que les brindan mediante los préstamos y se comprometen en cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido
texts.en:
The "Amados por Dios" (Beloved by God) communal bank is maD. up of 10 members. They have a lot in common and they all live in the same neighborhood of "Brisas D. California" (California Breezes). It is located above the entrance of los Ángeles in the district of Chosica - Lurigancho, in the department of Lima.

They work with EDAPROSPO (a Kiva field partner). Ms. Margarita L. assumed the position of president several days ago. A native of Tacna, she is unmarried and has been selling food for the past year. The members carry out many different economic activities. One of them sells beauty products, another is an independent cabinet maker. One sells meals to workers, another makes and sells chicken broth. Two members extract, process, and sell gold. One is a weaving teacher, another member does community service and sells handmaD. fabrics. Two proviD. taxi services.

Margarita will use the recently granted loan to buy large pots and cooking utensils. All the members wish to increase their profits and invest to increase their incomes so they can improve the quality of life and education for their children. The group members are grateful for the support that the loans bring them and they promise to make their payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy large pots and kitchen utensils

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
'In God We Trust' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Moses Diggs, 41 years old, married with 3 children aged 9-12 years old. Their educational levels  are 3rd-7th grade. Moses is a high school graduate but couldn't continue his education due to lack of financial support.

Moses' business is buying used shoes wholesale and selling them retail to the residents of downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He and his family live in Old Road, Joe Bar, south of the capital, Monrovia, Liberia. This community is mixed, with both poor and middle-class Liberians, but Moses happens to be a poor man.

Moses has been running this business for more than 5 years and is doing well. The location where Moses transacts business is ideal in that buyers see him before other vendors. Moses is hoping to establish a bigger store in the future so as to change the lives of himself and his family.

He needs this loan to purchase more used shoes wholesale to acquire more profit.

loans.use: to purchase more used shoes wholesale

loans.name: Los Angeles Group

texts.es:
La alcancía  comunal “Los Ángeles”; esta conformada por 10 socios, ellos  tienen como afinidad, de que todos viven en el mismo barrio de villa Pumacahuaga, son vecinos y se conocen desde hace mucho tiempo, esta ubicado en la entrada de los Ángeles del distrito chosica, departamento de Lima.

Trabajan con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad desde hace 8 meses, actualmente asume el cargo de presidenta la señorita Dora Maribel, natural de Tacna, soltera se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general desde hace 2 años. Los socios desempeñan diversas actividades, una de ellas a la venta prendas de vestir y accesorios, 2 prestan servicio domestico, 2 venden comidas, la otra presta servicio de  azafata, 2 se dedican venta de golosinas, una presta servicio de limpieza y la otra vende abarrotes en general.
Con el reciente préstamo otorgado a Dora lo invertirá en la compra de productos de primera necesidad y capital para la campaña navideña; piensa estudiar computación y también pastelería  ya que en el futuro le gustaría abrir una panadería.
Todos los socios tienen  el deseo de salir adelante, incrementar sus ganancias e invertir para mejorar sus ingresos, para mejorar la calidad de vida y educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
The "Los Ángeles” communal financial cooperative is made up of 10 partners. They all live in the same neighborhood, Pumacahuaga; they are neighbors and have known each other for a long time. The neighborhood is located at the Los Angeles entrance to the Chosica district, in the Department of Lima. The group has worked with EDAPROSPO – Prosperity for the past 8 months. Currently, Dora Maribel, originally from Tacna, has taken on the position of president. She is a single woman who has sold general groceries for the past two years. The partners carry out a range of business activities: one sells clothing and accessories; two provide domestic services; two sell food; another offers waitress services; two sell snacks; one provides cleaning services; and another sells general groceries. The funds from the loan offered to Dora will be invested in purchasing basic staple products and as capital for the Christmas marketing campaign. She is also thinking of taking computer courses and studying pastrymaking, since she would like to open a bakery in the future. All of the partners share the desire to improve their lives and increase their earnings, and to invest in expanding their incomes and raising their quality of life and the quality of their children's educations.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Will be invested in purchasing basic staple products and as capital for the Christmas marketing campaign

loans.name: Carla Karina

texts.es:
Carla tiene 23 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a su madre y sus dos hermanos  menores de 14 y 3 años de edad en el centro poblado menor San Agustín, ubicado en la carretera a Pimentel, a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Con el ahorro familiar y mucho sacrificio pudieron comprar una combi (vehículo con capacidad para 15 pasajeros) la cual inscribió en una compañía de transporte público que cubre la ruta Pimentel – Chiclayo, esta es la única fuente de ingreso con la cual se solventan los gastos económicos diarios y también los gastos de educación y cuidado de sus hermanos menores.

El continuo uso de esta unidad móvil ha hecho que empiece a sufrir considerables daños en el motor, dejándola fuera de operatividad, lo que le ha llevado a solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2500 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la reparación y en el mantenimiento general de su fuente de ingreso.

Carla sueña con tener una flota de vehículos dedicados al servicio de transporte público y también estudiar una carrera técnica de administración para seguir apoyando a su familia.

Ella es una joven muy responsable, sus vecinos la estiman mucho ya que siempre está dispuesta a ayudar cuando se la necesita.
texts.en:
Carla is 23 years old and single and lives with her mother and two younger siblings, 14 and 3 years old, in the small town of San Agustín, located on the highway to Pimental, 15 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. With her family's savings and great sacrifices, they were able to purchase a combi (a 15-passenger van) which was then registered with a public transportation company that covers the route between Pimental and Chiclayo. This is the only source of income with which they cover daily expenses as well as education and childcare expenses for her younger siblings. The continuous use of this vehicle has begun to cause considerable damage to its engine, leaving it inoperable. This is what has led her to request her first loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 2500 nuevos soles, which she plans to invest in the repair and general maintenance of her source of income. Carla dreams of owning a fleet of vehicles dedicated to public transportation as well as pursuing a technical degree in administration in order to continue supporting her family. She is a very responsible young woman whose neighbors greatly respect her because she is always happy to help when needed.

Translated from Spanish by Amanda McDermott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: repair and general maintenance of a vehicle

loans.name: Luisa María

texts.es:
Luisa es una madre de familia de 42 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y sus cuatro hijos a 25 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo, en el distrito de Santa Rosa.

Su esposo se dedica eventualmente a la pesca y, por lo difícil que es sostenerse con esta actividad, hace cinco años Luisa decidió apoyar a la economía familiar con el negocio de la venta de pescado fresco; empezó a vender pescado en las calles de forma ambulatoria y poco a poco su negocio ha ido creciendo, ahora ella lo vende en los pueblos de la región que no tienen acceso al mar y esporádicamente lo vende también en la ciudad de Tumbes, a seis horas de viaje desde la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Usualmente cuando viaja a Tumbes distribuye algunos pedidos que le solicitan con anticipación, pero la mayoría de veces lo vende en el mercado de la zona. Ella va a comprar su mercancía en el terminal pesquero de su distrito de dos a tres veces por semana, también vende pescado seco – salado el cual procesa en el mismo terminal.

Actualmente sus hijos están por terminar el colegio, Luisa desea brindarles la oportunidad de estudiar una carrera superior, pero los ingresos económicos que perciben de su negocio no le abastecen para lograr su deseo, es por ello que planea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más pescado para procesarlo y venderlo, por lo que está solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.

Ella desea seguir trabajando junto a su esposo para comprarse un auto y utilizarlo como vehículo de transporte de pasajeros en una empresa de automóviles que cubre la ruta Chiclayo – Santa Rosa.

Luisa ya ha trabajado con Edpyme Alternativa en otras oportunidades y en todas ellas ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad en sus pagos, por tal motivo es considerada como una cliente excelente.
texts.en:
Luisa is a 42-year old mother who lives with her husband and four children 25 minutes from the city of Chiclayo, in the Santa Rosa district. Her husband works from time to time as a fisherman, and since it is difficult to support a family with this activity, Luisa decided five years ago to support the family finances with a business selling fresh fish. She started to sell fish in the streets, and little by little her business grew. Now she sells in the towns of the region that don't have access to the sea and sporadically she also sells in the city of Tumbes, which is six hours from the city of Chiclayo. Generally when she travels to Tumbes she distributes some advance orders, but the majority of times she sells in the area market. She goes to purchase merchandise in the district fisheries terminal two or three times per week; she also sells salted dried fish that are processed there. Currently her children are about to finish school. Luisa would like to provide them with the opportunity to study in a university, but the income that her business generates is not sufficient to achieve this desire. For this reason she is planning on expanding her business with the purchase of more fish to process and sell, financed by a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 2000 nuevos soles. She wishes to continue working with her husband so that they can buy an automobile and to use it to transport passengers in a transportation business that covers the Chiclayo-Santa Rosa route. Luisa has worked with Edpyme Alternativa on other opportunities and in all of them she has demonstrated responsibility and punctuality in her payments, and for this reason she is considered to be an excellent client.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase fish to process and sell

loans.name: Clotilde

texts.es:
Clotilde tiene 39 años, es soltera y vive en casa de su hermano en el distrito de Reque, ubicado a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace 8 meses tiene un pequeño restaurante que funciona en casa de su hermano, el cual atiende junto a su cuñada; la idea del negocio nació de su cuñada, la cual ya había tenido un restaurante en Jaén antes de mudarse a Reque, ellas empezaron a trabajar con la venta de cerveza  y luego, con sus propios recursos, han podido ampliar su negocio.

El establecimiento tiene muy buena acogida debido a la calidad del servicio y a la buena sazón de los platos que prepara Clotilde, sus clientes potenciales son los agricultores que trabajan cerca, aunque también atiende a personas de la ciudad e incluso a algunos turistas.

Con las ganancias de este negocio Clotilde apoya a sus padres enviándoles dinero, debido a que son de edad avazada y ya no pueden trabajar. Todos los dias  da lo mejor de sí para sacar su negocio adelante, fruto de este negocio es que ha construido un pequeño ambiente en el segundo piso el cual piensa utilizar como un segundo salón para atencion a sus clientes.

Clotilde se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alernativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de materiales de construcción para hacer los acabados en la pieza que está construyendo.

Ella sueña con hacer crecer su establecimiento y tener su casa propia, Clotilde es una mujer muy trabajadora y empeñosa, sus clientes y vecinos la consideran una persona responsable y amable.
texts.en:
Clotilde is 39 years old, single, and lives in her brother's house in the Reque district, located 15 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For the last 8 months she has had a small restaurant in her brother's house, which she runs with her sister-in-law. The idea for the restaurant originated with her sister-in-law, who had already had a restaurant in Jaen before moving to Reque.
